question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding absence seizures?

options.A: Carbamazepine is effective
options.B: Ethosuximide can cause status in absence seizures
options.C: The pathophysiology is related to T calcium channels
options.D: Absence seizures typically originate in the frontal lobe

question_text: What is true about Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME)?

options.A: Can be provoked by photic stimulation
options.C: Typically presents with myoclonic jerks on awakening

question_text: An elderly male with a history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and ischemic heart disease presented with an episode of loss of consciousness preceded by sweating and palpitations. The episode lasted a few seconds, and he immediately regained full baseline. His heart rate was borderline low at 50 beats per minute. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Typical syncope
33-year-old with a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizure with an aura of a rising abdominal sensation. What is the most likely localization of the seizure focus?
patient experiences an abdominal rising sensation and déjà vu. Which localization is most likely associated with this pathophysiology?

45-year-old patient with a known case of diabetes mellitus (DM) and hypertension (HTN) presents with new onset seizure. A brain MRI shows a left temporal lesion (cavernoma). What is the most appropriate next step?
28-year-old female with a hemorrhagic lesion in the brain had a staring episode followed by post-event confusion. Which of the following is a suitable antiepileptic medication?

question_text: An elderly patient with a history of diabetes mellitus (DM), hypertension (HTN), and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) came with decreased level of consciousness (LOC). His wife mentioned that he told her he was seeing animals before deteriorating. A CT scan showed left occipital hypodensity. What will you do?

options.A: CTA
Irreversible visual loss
Phenytoin
Used primarily for Parkinson’s disease
options.B: An anti-epileptic drug used in seizure management

options.A: 5-year-old child presents with cognitive decline since 7 months of age and has frequent spasms with hypsarrhythmia. After receiving ACTH, there was some improvement. What is the likely diagnosis?
30-year-old patient with seizures controlled on antiepileptic drugs (AED) developed facial redness and fatigue. What is the most likely AED causing these side effects?
patient with features of Rolandic epilepsy presents with what EEG finding?

question_text: In a patient with occipital seizure and migraine with aura, which of the following is in favor of visual aura?

options.A: Circular coloring
pregnant patient at 12 weeks GA with migraine came with status migrainosus. What is the management?

question_text: Which of the following characteristics is associated with pain in glossopharyngeal neuralgia?

options.A: Lasting from a few seconds to two minutes
options.C: Electric shock-like, shooting, stabbing, or sharp in quality

question_text: What is the first-line treatment for glossopharyngeal neuralgia?

options.A: Carbamazepine (CBZ)
known case of migraine, a female patient in her 1st trimester, came to the ER with a headache. What is the treatment?
patient presents with a small area of headache associated with hair loss. What is the most appropriate treatment?

patient recently had a baby delivered by C-section one day ago and came to the ED with a headache that increases while sitting and coughing. Brain MRI showed normal results, and the neurological exam was normal. What will you do next?

question_text: In a scenario of SUNA (Short-lasting Unilateral Neuralgiform headache attacks with conjunctival injection and tearing), what is the first line treatment?

options.A: Lamotrigine

question_text: Which of the following features would be most supportive of a diagnosis of medication-overuse headache (MOH) in a patient?

options.A: Absence of neck pain
patient presents with unilateral headache on a daily basis associated with ptosis and lacrimation. What is the diagnosis?

question_text: Patient came with tongue pain and paresthesia, radiating to the neck, increased with neck movement; what is the diagnosis?

options.A: Neck-tongue syndrome
